lines.text: There is a moment every winter when I remember that childhood winter. The winter of the Anschluss. The winter that Hitler invaded our country and took away all that my family and I held dear.
I'm proud of being Jewish.
I am holding something in my hand, Countess Zora. Does it penetrate your mind?
Um... it is a... rather dirty hair pin!
What's that song?
I don't know. My brother taught it to me.
I like it.
I stood in front of your building all day, waiting for you to go in or out.
I'm sorry. I didn't know.
I know.
We were at the hospital all day.
Ladies, we are supposed to be exercising our bodies, not our mouths.

[to the teacher]
Thanks for the clarification.
[to Inge]
Exercising doesn't seem to be doing her body much good.
We are cleaning God's earth. There is no shame in that.
Stay away from my brother, Lise. He's wicked and he's cruel.
Then Lise's brother Heinz is the boy who tried to kill your mother but succeeded only in breaking my leg.
But it doesn't change the way I feel inside.
Well, it changes the way I feel inside!
They dehumanize us. They debase us. And they're not going to stop because of a plebescite.
Lise, go to your seat.
This is my seat.
You're not taking anything you don't need, are you?
No, Mother. Nothing I don't need.
I think we both knew then that we would never see each other again. But when I look back at my life, at the people who really mattered, I see Lise. She is still the best friend I ever had.
